title: UK’s eurocrat says Brexit WON’T harm intelligence power & rubbishes Major's 'sour' claim
text:
UK’s eurocrat says Brexit WON’T harm intelligence power & rubbishes Major's 'sour' claim UK’s eurocrat says Brexit WON’T harm intelligence power & rubbishes Major's 'sour' claim BRITAIN’s top eurocrat today insisted Brexit won’t affect the UK’s intelligence sharing with EU member states. PUBLISHED: 18:00,   18:37, Tue, Feb 28, 2017 
Sir Julian King, who was appointed Britain’s European Commissioner last summer, this afternoon told MPs there was “no reason” why the exchange of core intelligence information should alter once the UK quits the EU. 
The former ambassador, who has taken on the European Commission’s security brief, also dismissed ex-prime minister Sir John Major’s suggestion there is a “sour” atmosphere ahead of Brexit talks. 
Sir Julian described Britain as a “known and valued partner” and outlined a “shared interest” between the UK and EU member states in continuing intelligence and security co-operation. 
He described terrorism and cyber crime as the biggest current threats to the EU. PARLIAMENT.TV Sir Julian King played down Sir John Major’s claims of a 'sour' atmosphere ahead of Brexit talks Related articles ‘Come off it sunshine’ Boris Johnson hits back at Sir John Major 
Sir Julian told the House of Commons’ Home Affairs Select Committee: “In combating these threats, no matter how good you are - and the UK is recognised across the rest of the EU as very good in this area - you are still better off if you are able to work with partners. 
“That applies on core intelligence and applies on wider law enforcement co-operation. 
“On the core intelligence side there are exchanges but they take place outside the EU framework. 
“There’s no reason why those in their current form should be affected by this process.” 
But Sir Julian added there are also “extensive” security exchanges as part of EU membership which “make a significant contribution to the security of all of the EU member states”. I haven't experienced a sour atmosphere. Sir Julian King 
Despite agreeing both the EU and UK want to continue co-operating on security issues post-Brexit, Sir Julian suggested that may not be the case. 
He said: “On this and on various other things… in the end fundamentally because of the shared interest where there's a will there's very often a way. 
“But if everyone agrees you should do something doesn't mean it is necessarily straightforward and easy to do.” 
Asked by Tory MP Ranil Jayawardena whether it was right to assume there would be a “grown-up” agreement between the remaining 27 EU member states and the UK on security matters due to the common threats faced by both, Sir Julian highlighted “legal constraints and practical constraints”. 
He also adopted the European Commission’s hardline view that a practical divorce agreement would have to be negotiated first before the EU and UK could discuss their post-Brexit relationship. The Best Trade Prospects for the UK Thu, February 16, 2017
